text: In 1987, the International Space University was founded to develop and implement international space-related curriculum. This university would identify, assemble, and educate a new generation of young leaders from around the world. By uniting these students in an intensive program of study and research, ISU would foster long-lasting ties between these future heads of industry, government, and academia, creating an international network which would help assure cooperation in the opening of space. In the summer of 1988, that mission was accomplished and the International Space University was born. For the first summer session of the International Space University, 104 of the world's top graduate level students from 21 nations came together on the campus of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Having undergone a rigorous selection program, these students participated in an experience that would change their lives and quite possibly the world forever. So what we are going to talk about and what you are going to listen to and what you are going to take part in in the next 10 weeks is much more important than just a learning experience. It is a creative experience. You are creating your future. There is nothing more important because in your future lies the history and the future of the human species. The ISO class of 88 is going to be a major component in the space leadership of the world in the future. These are impressive young professionals with a formidable list of credentials to their credit. They are gifted with enormous intelligence and unbelievable resources of energy. For over 60 days and nights these students were immersed in one of the most rigorous and intensive space education programs ever organized. From the world's space powers to those nations only now on the threshold of utilizing space technology, ISU has something to offer everyone. The whole process involves, or the training involves, a look at all communication technologies and using satellites for remote sensing, monitoring the growth of forests or the spread of forests all over the place, and, in my country, this is one of the technologies we require, and we'll use this to implement these facilities. I had a few ideas about space and what does space means, but when I came here to ISU, and after the completion of this program, two-month intensive program, I can say that I learned a lot during this program. Including 240 hours of lectures and instruction by leading experts from 14 nations, students are exposed to the latest ideas in all fields of space development, exploration, technology, and administration. Stressing a multidisciplinary approach to education, ISU has developed courses in the following eight departments of space studies. Architecture, business and management, engineering, life sciences, policy and law, resources and manufacturing, satellite applications, physical sciences. The quality of the lectures we've had here has been just superb. We've had experts in space business. For example, the Chief Designer of the Shuttle, Sire Rubinstein has come in. He is now President of Brockwell Space Transportation Systems, and he has talked to us about what it means to be involved in space business. What better perspective could you have? We met the best in the field. I mean professor wise and lecturer wise. And we saw insight or view that we never could see it from school or from anywhere else. Normally confined to one or two areas of specialization, ISU students are taught the importance of broad-based knowledge, developing the skills necessary to effectively work in a multi-disciplinary environment. To accomplish this goal, each session students work on a simulation of a major space project. During the 1988 session, they spent over 280 hours working with interdisciplinary teams, which planned and designed a viable lunar base for research and industry. Hands-on experiments such as this one are vital to giving students and faculty a feel for the real problems that are involved in space operations. And no student who has operated the system will be able have any doubts about whether or not it's possible to control machinery in real time on the moon. The multidisciplinary approach that this program took has been a real eye opener. ISU students represent a global network of expertise and talent, a benefit which is of extreme importance in this global economy. What's important is experience of getting to know other people, getting a current base, you know the people when you have to talk to them in the future, and everything's going to be so much easier when you can negotiate with friends than with people you've never met before. So it needs a lot of international collaboration in the future to establish a space station or a lunar base. What I will go away with is a base of contacts all over the world, of people who are my age or approximately my age who have my motivation are interested in the things that I'm interested in. And that is an incredible bomb to have. ISU is going to be the training ground for those savvy individuals who know how to operate in this world marketplace and know how to cut across the boundaries of governments and corporations to pull together projects and programs and make them work. ISU is looking to the future, and that future is bright. After four more summer sessions hosted at the world's greatest educational institutions, ISU will open the doors on its first permanent campus during the International Space Year 1992. From this central campus, ISU will beam lectures and teleconferences to advance students and researchers at daughter campuses around the world. The goal of ISU is to become the first true space university at the dawn of the 21st century with students and faculty actually studying and working in space. Eric Comey, C.E. I think the ISU concept, as well as other concepts like this, is the absolute seedbed to spring new ideas in innovation into our total process. The ISU is building international bridges. To move out into space is going to be very, very expensive. And I think if we're going to do it seriously, we are going to have to do it as an international endeavour. I think the ISU plants the seeds of international cooperation and demonstrates the benefits to its student body and that can only be to the good in the long run. Space is going to invade all the areas of our being in the next 20 or 30 years and it's in everybody's interest to make sure that it's there, it's free, it's international and it's forward-looking. if I had any money, I would put it in. Dozens of space organizations and sponsors have stepped forward to support the ISU dream of a new worldwide network of young leaders who have the capabilities and drive to push their nations and companies into leading roles as we enter the 21st century. These visionary sponsors see the International Space University as the important investment that it is. By supporting an ISU student today, They are creating a leader for tomorrow. As the people of Earth take their first steps outward into the solar system, we are faced with a choice. Do we do it alone or together? Will we carry on as we have for thousands of years, or do we try something new? The students of the International Space University are ready to accept the challenge of tomorrow now. Together, we can reach the stars. I'm just kidding. . And now I am here. ¶¶ The Emblem of the Dead Thank you. See you next week. Thank you. like me Thank you. Thank you. Bowls House Oh, oh, oh, oh, oh, oh, oh, oh, oh, oh, oh, oh, oh, oh, oh, oh, oh, oh, oh, oh, oh, oh, oh, oh, oh, oh, oh, oh, oh, oh guitar solo Good timing, coach. Thank you. Ready? Greetings to all you gathered for the first graduation ceremony of the International Space University. I send especially warm wishes to my colleagues at MIT, my old friend Roy Gibson, and the men behind the ISU. Peter Diamandis, Todd Hawley, Bob Richard and their colleagues. I'm particularly pleased that I can greet you while remaining comfortably at home on the other side of the Earth. I never really expected the commsats would be so useful to me personally. In fact, I never expected to see them in my lifetime. You are the first representatives of a true space-faring species whose world is not bounded by the confines of one planet. So let me share with you a passage I wrote back in 1969 for the history of the Apollo 11 mission, first on the moon. Half a billion years ago, the moon summoned life out of its first home, the sea, and led it onto the empty land. For as it drew the tides across the barren continents of primeval Earth, their daily rhythm exposed to the sun and air the creatures of the shadows. Most perished but some adapted to the new and hostile environment. The conquest of the land had begun. We shall never know when this happened on the shores of what vanished sea. There were no eyes or cameras to record the event. Now the moon calls again and this time life responds with a roar that shakes the sky. When a Saturn V soars spacewards on 4,000 tons of thrust, it signifies more than a trance of technology. It opens the next chapter of evolution. Well, that was written in 1969. And we're going to return to the moon. But when we go there again, it will be in vehicles that will make the Saturn V, for all its staggering complexity and its 150 million horsepower, look like a clumsy, inefficient dinosaur of the early space age. And this time, we will stay. Space travel is a technological mutation that really should not have arrived until the 21st century. But thanks to the ambition and genius of men like Werner von Braun and Sergei Korolyov and their influence upon such diverse individuals as Kennedy and Khristelf, the moon was reached half a century ahead of time. And now you can take advantage of this historical accident, for as I.s. Newton once remarked, you are standing on the shoulders of giants. The moon was a fitting subject for our efforts during the first session of the ISU. Do not lose the momentum of your work, or the intensity of your vision, whatever obstacles you may encounter. As H.T. Wells once put it, the choice is universe or nothing. The resources of that universe are, by all human standards, infinite. There are no limits to growth among the stars. Unfortunately, there's a tragic mismatch between our present needs and our capabilities. The conquest of space will not arrive soon enough to save millions from leading starved and stunted lives. Thus it is all the more urgent that we exploit to the utmost the marvelous tools that space technology has already given us COMSTATs WEALERSATs GEOSATs Earth resources SATs and all the other SATs yet to be invented. this is a reason as I've said many times in the past that the third world needs space technology even more urgently than the so-called developing world you will find in the years to come that the experience which you have shared with your fellow ISU students will have changed your life to work with friends from a score of other nations will profoundly affect your world view and that may well be the most important role of the ISU. As our terrestrial universities once first flourished during the times of great exploration and discovery on our own planet so the ISU is a response to the first exploration of space. The blossoming of art and science during the Renaissance may now be repeated when artists and poets join scientists and engineers at the new frontier as the university begins its second year in Europe and later in other locations around the globe I eagerly await its growth to a permanent full-time institution which will train tomorrow's space professionals I would like to know the future that you will help to create but that is a privilege to be reserved for your children and grandchildren it is they who to quote H.G. Wells again shall stand upon this earth as one stands upon a footstool and reach yet their hand among the stars I wish you well for you represent a new evolutionary branch of humanity Congratulations on your achievement and my very best wishes for your futures in space Thank you and goodbye Bye.

international space-related curriculum.
This university would identify, assemble, and educate
a new generation of young leaders from around the world.
By uniting these students in an intensive program
of study and research, ISU would foster long-lasting ties

in the future. These are impressive young professionals with a formidable list of
credentials to their credit. They are gifted with enormous intelligence and
unbelievable resources of energy. For over 60 days and nights these students

I send especially warm wishes

So let me share with you a passage

Half a billion years ago,
the moon summoned life
out of its first home, the sea,
and led it onto the empty land.
For as it drew the tides
across the barren continents of primeval Earth,
their daily rhythm
exposed to the sun and air
the creatures of the shadows.

and hostile environment.
The conquest of the land had begun.
We shall never know when this happened
on the shores of what vanished sea.
There were no eyes or cameras
to record the event.
Now the moon calls again
and this time life responds
with a roar that shakes the sky.
When a Saturn V soars spacewards on 4,000 tons of thrust,
it signifies more than a trance of technology.
It opens the next chapter of evolution.
Well, that was written in 1969.
And we're going to return to the moon.
But when we go there again,
it will be in vehicles that will make the Saturn V,
for all its staggering complexity and its 150 million horsepower,
look like a clumsy, inefficient dinosaur
of the early space age.
And this time, we will stay.
Space travel is a technological mutation
that really should not have arrived
until the 21st century.
But thanks to the ambition and genius
of men like Werner von Braun and Sergei Korolyov
and their influence upon such diverse individuals
as Kennedy and Khristelf,
the moon was reached
half a century ahead of time.
And now you
can take advantage of this historical
accident, for
as I.s. Newton once remarked,
you are standing on the shoulders
of giants.
The moon was a
fitting subject for our efforts during the
first session of the ISU.
Do not lose the
momentum of your work,
or the intensity of your vision,
whatever obstacles you may encounter.
As H.T. Wells once put it,
the choice is universe or nothing.
The resources of that universe are,
by all human standards, infinite.
There are no limits to growth among the stars.
Unfortunately, there's a tragic mismatch
between our present needs and our capabilities.
The conquest of space will not arrive soon enough to save millions from leading starved and stunted lives.
Thus it is all the more urgent that we exploit to the utmost
the marvelous tools that space technology has already given us
